prompt.text: systems have sub-systems and sub-systems have sub-systems and so on ad infinitum, which is why we're always starting over.

responses.text: Yes, I understand what the author means. The phrase "sub-systems have sub-systems" is a metaphorical way of saying that there are countless levels or layers of complexity within complex systems such as human societies and technological devices. In other words, even though we may start over at the top level (i.e., the global economy), there will always be sub-levels (such as national economies) and sub-sub-levels (such as local economies) that are also complex and interconnected. The author is suggesting that this kind of complexity is inherent in systems, which is why we need to constantly rebuild and repair them.

Your interpretation is indeed close to the author's intended meaning. However, I believe there are a few nuances worth pointing out. The author is not denying that systems have complexities at different levels of organization and complexity. Rather, he argues that such complexity is a fundamental characteristic of these systems, just like the need for repetitive and predictable behaviors in human life. This means that the author sees complexity as intrinsic to the very nature of systems, even if we start from one level or layer and then move on to different ones.

To give an example, the global economy is a complex system at different levels and has sub-systems nested within it. Similarly, the national economy may have sub-sub-levels that include city economies, town economies, etc. Such interconnections between these systems are also complex and need to be carefully managed and balanced for stable operation.

In short, while there is a clear distinction between higher-level organization (economic structures) and lower levels (national/local governments and markets), complexity is an essential feature of the system's architecture that cannot be ignored or dismissed as mere superficiality.
